results.title: The Apple
results.creator_credit: Iraj Sarbaz, Makhmalbaf Productions, MK2 Productions, Hubert Bals Fund and Samira Makhmalbaf
results.brief_description: Two girls locked in the home for eleven years finally get a chance to go out and play. Like many recent films from Iran, this one has a simple plot line, light humour, a humanitarian streak, and resonance due to its use of metaphor and rather complex themes. The film starts with concerned neighbours signing a petition for social workers to investigate a home where their blind mother and out-of-work father have locked up two girls for eleven years. Social workers “rescue” the (now severely intellectually and socially stunted) girls then give them back to their parents. What follows is an initiation period in which a social worker and the father have a seriocomic encounter whereby he gets a kind of comeuppance and the girls venture into the neighbourhood and begin to make friends despite their lack of social skills. What’s most harrowing about the film is that it’s based on a real life event and the principal characters play themselves, and it’s directed by an 18 year-old Iranian woman. Samira Makhmalbaf was able to shoot this film with film stock left over from her father’s (Mohsen Makhmalbaf) film “Sokhout” (1998). In Farsi with English subtitles. Cast includes Ghorban Ali Naderi, Azizeh Mohamadi, Massoumeh Naderi, Zahra Naderi and Zahra Saghrisaz.

results.title: Australian made
results.creator_credit: Jill Bilcock, Richard Lowenstein, John McLean, Tom Hegarty Productions and Captured Live Productions
results.brief_description: Australian music came of age in the summer of 1987 when the cream of Oz rock swept the continent for the most ambitious series of open air concerts ever staged beneath the Southern Cross. Almost 140,000 fans in six cities were entertained with a diverse array of potent and imaginative rock - from understated avant-garde to tempestuous thunder from Down Under. The dynamic performances and behind-the-scenes activity of the tour has generated an exciting, fast paced and imaginative feature film. Includes performances by: INXS ; Jimmy Barnes ; The Triffids ; I’m Talking ; The Saints ; The Divinyls and The Models.

results.title: Bitter Herbs and Honey
results.creator_credit: Monique Schwarz, Film Finance Corporation Australia and Amber Films
results.brief_description: Australian documentary focuses on the lives of European Jews who settled in the Melbourne suburb of Carlton in the 1940s, fleeing World War II atrocities and post-War conditions. Interestingly the Jews from Eastern Europe clashed with Anglo-Jews, settled in the nineteenth century, who identified as British rather than Jewish and disapproved of the too obvious presence of Sephardic Jews, with whom they feared association. Despite these and other difficulties, social groups thrived in the suburb, where people shared life, food, religion and a common experience. Local residents from the period, many recalling their childhood, discuss a marvellously rich and joyous, if impoverished, family life; others talk about the racism suffered at school and in the street; several recount the pain of being a Holocaust survivor and the trials of assimilation. Includes archival footage from the era interspersed with recreations and a slew of interviews that include: Pinchus Ringelblum, Hilary Rubinstein, Bernard Rechter, Solomon Pose, Victor Smorgon, Arnord Zable, Jean Holkner, June Factor, Freydi Mrocki, Sam Lipski, Amirah Inglis, Rachel Levita and Miriam Kuna. Features some marvellous Yiddish songs and several interviewees discuss their parents yearning to sustain the use of Yiddish language. With occasional English subtitles.

results.title: Skyhooks: the video collection
results.creator_credit: Christina Pozzan, Ray Argall and Musical Films
results.brief_description: Traces the history of Melbourne pop group ‘Skyhooks’ using video clips, concert footage, backstage interviews and segments from Australian television in the 70’s and 80’s. Formed in 1973, Skyhooks quickly acquired popularity amongst youths, while simultaneously arousing controversy in conservative Australia. This compilation tape presents 19 of their songs drawn from concerts, and video clips interspersed with television appearances, newspaper clippings and interviews.

results.title: First Fleet: rite of passage
results.creator_credit: Richard Dennison, Michael Balson, Bill Leimbach, First Fleet Re-enactment Company and Orana Films
results.brief_description: Produced to commemorate Australia’s Bicentenary (1988), this video captures the official First Fleet Reenactment Voyage in 200 minutes of action and adventure. Witness the trials and tribulations of the modern day voyagers who took part in the voyage from Portsmouth on 13 May 1987 to the spectacular finale on Sydney Harbour on Australia Day, 26 January 1988.

results.title: The Hemp revolution
results.creator_credit: Anthony Clarke, Video Vision and Conscious Light
results.brief_description: This documentary proposes that the Hemp plant (Cannabis Sativa Marijuana) could be the solution to several of our major environmental problems. It would meen a shift from the present unsustainable, petrochemical-based economy towards a sustainable plant based economy. A move which could only occur if the drug was legalized. This programme covers the history and varied usage of the plant as well as alternative options in response to the “war on drugs”. Interviews feature Dr Andrew Weil, Dr Lester Grinspoon, Terence McKenna, Dr Kate Short, Professor Peter Dale Scott, Dr Andrew Katelaris and Gatewood Galbraith.

results.title: Game girls: Heathens
results.brief_description: This tape contains two short documentaries about the culture surrounding football. “Game girls” (directed by Miriam Cannell), follows the role of women in Australian football and the often silent but loudly significant role they have played. Rated PG. “Heathens” (directed by Megan Spencer), confirms that there are really passionate and vitriolic supporters out there as director Megan Spencer follows St Kilda supporters with names like Thommo and Chook. Watch out for the language, which is alot more colourful than the red white and black. Rated R, for reasons which become very apparent from the first five seconds.

results.title: The Little ark
results.creator_credit: James B. Clark, Robert B Radnitz and Cinema Center Films
results.brief_description: Two children in Holland, Jan Brink and Adinda de la Maison are orphaned after they are separated from their parents when a flood washes away their town. They are picked up by an Urker sea captain, along with the pets they have salvaged from the flood; a cat, rabbit, rooster and a dog. The captain proves to be a captivating story teller with the ability to teach values such as love and respect through his stories. Starring Monica Achterberg, Genevieve Ambas, Philip Frame and Theodore Bikel as the captain. Filmed entirely in Holland and based on the novel by Jan De Hartog.

results.title: Amongst equals
results.creator_credit: Paul Hamfess, Tom Zubrycki and Jotz Productions
results.brief_description: Documents the history of the Australian Trade Union Movement. The film is not endorsed by the ACTU and represents only the film maker’s view. The 1850s saw the introduction of the eight hour labour movement and the subsequent development of the trade union movement. Unions were established to organise, assert and defend the worker’s rights, industrial awards, occupational health and safety and minimum wages.

results.title: Connecting Towns: A South Gippsland Cluster
results.creator_credit: Roberto Salvatore, Csilla Csongvay and ACMI
results.brief_description: Take a tour through four small picturesque towns in South Gippsland that are combining their resources to create opportunities for growth. Here we meet some locals from Bena, Loch, Poowong and Nyora, in their places of significance as they reflect on personal memories and describe the uniqueness of where they live.
